A couple of decades later and I've finally gotten around to hearing the story first hand told by McCourt himself and I was not disappointed. The struggles, the loss and the hardship experienced by Frank and his family is something I could not even imagine based on the way I was brought up. However, the author tells the story in quite a comical fashion that ensures that laughter often prevails over the horror that was their life. McCourt also writes in a way that is simple to understand, almost as though the story itself is being told by a child or adolescent. I find this helps to really put yourself in the shoes of a young Frank McCourt and understand what his perspective on things was at that time. He has a terrific memory when recounting all of his encounters, conversations & stories. Everything everyone says is so detailed I find myself impressed at how he was able to recall so much from events that happened so long ago. Maybe it's just the fact that his life was so traumatic that everything really became engraved in his mind. Anyway, it's a really great read and will certainly go down in history was a non-fiction modern classic.

<< Life-Through a New, Refreshing Lens (Review of Angela's Ashes)  A family, deeply weakened by death, alcohol, and poverty. If you feel like your life has gotten into an uncomfortable groove, you must read this, for this book will add some spice to your life for sure; “Angela’s Ashes”, a truly stunning and heart-wrenching memoir about the author, Frank McCourt’s childhood in the poverty-stricken city of Limerick in Ireland, will hit you like a tidal wave. Optimistic and hopeful, McCourt uses graphic realistic details, characterization, and the enchanting theme of childhood to craft this wonderful story about poverty, perseverance, and just being a kid, gracefully.  It think it is very easy to say that watching a movie is considerably less difficult than reading a book. All you do is watch images and hear sounds. Passionate and heart filled, the way Frank McCourt writes this book, with awing and lifelike details makes the words pop out into a movie. You can envision the drunken dad coming home every day without money and singing his usual songs. You can envision impoverished people begging outside the local church. You can hear the babies wailing in the streets, the mothers crying over deceased loved ones. Frank McCourt writes with telling details put insane, high-definition, 50-inch flat-screen TVs in the reader’s head. Readers that have never been to Ireland will surely know what it looks like after reading Angela’s Ashes!   Distinct and diverse, the people surrounding Frank McCourt’s life are all unique in their own way. The extremely alcoholic father who would rather buy a beer than pay for his little baby’s funeral and casket, the weeping mom, the spirited little brother, the extremely inquisitive classmate...and the list of characters simply just goes on. All the characters have an affect on Frank McCourt, and soon enough they start to affect your life, and the way you think.   We all remember our childhood days. Ahhhh, those days of freedom and innocence! Well, Frank McCourt writes as if he is a child, and throughout the entire book you visit the mind of a very curious and innocent child. Quiet and observant, he writes of things like seeing his mother beg for food, and his father waste away from alcohol, very innocently. And as the book goes on, and more and more tragic and mind awakening experiences happen, you may observe that he slowly starts to lose that innocence. You see him age not only physically, but mentally. This reoccurring theme of childhood pops out at you throughout whole story. There is something that people of all ages can relate to and enjoy about the mind of a child.   It’s amazing how something as small as a book can change a person’s life, and turn it in a whole new direction of thinking. The many components and themes of Angela’s Ashes will click on a luminescent light bulb in your head, and soon you will view everything in a different light. It will be like seeing life through a whole new lens – a refreshing feeling nobody minds.

Stunning. Absolutely stunning. What an amazing way of telling your life's story. Or at least the story of your first nineteen years on this earth. This didn't read like a memoir, full of funny stories and important, yet fleeting figures, that all combine in the end to give a moral or a lesson. Rather this is just a raw and honest look at a hard life.When I talk to people about Angela's Ashes most have the reaction of, "Oh my gosh it's such a sad book." Or "I loved that book." Or variations on the two. The former reaction seemed to come from people without strong Irish heritage. The latter- Irish. There's a bitter humor that runs throughout the book. A very, what I've come to realize is an Irish humor.If asked- I'm American. Really, most of my family has been in this country since it was first founded. But when tracing family lineage I'm a strong 25% German, and the rest of me is Irish. Maybe just a dash of French, Scottish and English thrown in there- but mostly Irish. I found myself laughing at so many things, that other people, without that bitter, biting, Irish sense of humor would find unsettling. There is an Irish personality I've noticed, especially after reading this book and thinking about my family. We laugh at hardships, they (or at least Frank) laughed at hardships.Yes, Frank McCourt had an extremely hard life. Yes, there were dispicable things happening, disturbing and sad. But he writes it all with such an innocent and storylike quality to it, you feel that he's kindly putting up a window so you're not right in it, and you can watch in comfort.His style of writing is so unique as well. It's story-telling done so well you have trouble remembering this all really happened. There are depressing moments, there are touching moments, and like I keep saying there are many funny moments.Angela's Ashes is a perfect book to help you really remember that life is what you make it. Shit is going to be thrown at you, but you can't let it weigh you down. You can change your circumstances. Yes, it's hard work, but with determination and the ability not to take it all so seriously, you can turn things around your way. And really, things aren't so bad.Oh- I guess there was a moral here. Well done, McCourt. Well done.

I haven't picked this book up since middle school, but damn, it was still as powerful.Frank McCourt recounts his childhood in the Irish slums with such tenacity, hilarity, and vividness; that you feel as if you are there with him. So I remember when this engrossing memoir was all the rage back in the late 90's, around the time Ireland was experiencing an economic resurgence and trends like Riverdance and pubs were becoming popular in America. All I heard about this book was that it was "sad".So imagine my surprise when I didn't find the novel to be merely "sad". Although the author tells the story of a childhood riddled with poverty, loneliness, and saddest of all (in my eyes), little kindness, encouragement or affection; in spite of all this, he tells his story with humor of all things! It reminds me of a wise woman who said that life will either make you laugh or cry, and why not laugh because crying gives you a headache.The book makes you feel as if you're living with the McCourt household in 1930's New York and later Ireland as they beg a pig's head for Christmas dinner, nail tires to their shoes when they start to wear out, experience typhoid fever, consumption and tuberculosis, and watch their father drink away his wages again, and again, and again. It sounds pretty dark on paper, but somehow McCourt made me chuckle and smile at every turn.If you have experienced the nature of addiction (and remember that the author's alcoholic father can't exactly join AA back in those days, and don't forget the worshiped role of booze in Irish culture), it isn't surprising but no less astonishing that a person can be so supremely selfish. Indeed, McCourt brings out one of the tragic truths of humanity - that you can love someone for the good that's in them, despite the fact that they are incapable of loving you back. (LOVE, of course, is an action, not just a feeling).I don't feel that I necessarily admire the author, despite his ultimate victory over poverty, but neither do I begrudge him his financial success through his writing. People have criticized him for making money off of his misfortunes, of falsifying events and so on. Since MccCourt wrote his memoir while in his 60's, I take it for granted that unless he has a photographic memory, the novel reflects his feelings and impressions of his upbringing, uses liberal creative license, and is not a verbatim report of past events. But I think he is honest to the spirit of things. He makes no qualms about admitting that he was many times dishonest and shady in order to reach his goals, whether it was finding bread to eat or scraping up the fare to immigrate back to America, the land of his birth. The author himself recognizes that he is an unscrupulous opportunist; are we really surprised that this disadvantaged boy would grow up to make a fortune off of the misery of his past life? I'm happy for the guy and hope he's finally at peace now, having passed away in 2009.

I have to admitt this book sat on my shelf for a while. I kept passing it over for another book. Grant it, I didn't see the movie, but people told me it's a sad story about a very poor family. What really do we have to complain about? We have a roof over our heads, food in our bellies, clothes on our bodies, and shoes on our feet. Gosh...My son woke up from his nap yesterday as I was reading about Frank McCourt. He walks down the hallway in clean PJ's, a diaper, in the protection of our home, and is looking for a cold glass of milk and a snack. How lucky is he? This furthers my desire to move my family abroad and live off the land. Unfortunately, it goes from bad to worse, if that is possible. Frank loses sister's and brother's, doesn't have shoes nor a change of clothes. Rarey do they have food and it's tea and bread for days, even weeks. They often don't have a decent place to stay since they have no money. A father who spends his time hugging his pint then this children. Disease is ramptant. Winter is unbearable. And it goes on and on... Very endearing.

This book is so very sad: extreme poverty, starvation, diseases, neglect, and so many dead children. The most terrible thing in my opinion in these situations is the parents' neglect of their children, and their blindness about it, their ignorance about it. Or how can there be almost no happiness in a kid's life? I am very happy for you that you can't answer these question. But what bothered me was the abrupt ending, I think McCourt could omit the last story that was not really related to the book, instead of fully opening a new chapter that does not get enough attention or closure. The author remains for me, "Mr. McCourt," because he was my English teacher in High School. Sometimes he brought in drafts of sections from this book (and, I believe, the next one as well) and read them aloud in class. This might not be seen as a particularly useful pedagogical exercise, if observed by a school administrator or board member, but in fact it served a higher purpose - that of inspiring us as students to strive to use the English language in the most perfect way possible in order to express and explore our thoughts.This book is also an inspiration. In spite of its many descriptions of grinding poverty, childhood illnesses, and constant hunger, it consistently demonstrates a human spirit that transcends its circumstances and recreates itself through perseverance, luck, and wit. Frank McCourt learns in spite of teachers who who promote stupidity, hopes in spite of a world that says he can never accomplish anything, loves in spite of dullness and hatred. I once heard a self-proclaimed "intellectual" on PBS describe this book as a depressing example "Irish rage," shortly before he admitted that he hadn't read the book. In fact, it is as close to an opposite of that as one could achieve. Far from depressing, it is uplifting, because the choices young Frank makes allow him to escape circumstances that would destroy other individuals. Far from being specific to the Irish experience, it is universal in its application, because each person faces the same possibility of limitation due to social surroundings, and the same struggle to overcome them. Far from noisy rage, it seems to me a symphony of humanity that demonstrates the harmony possible in this world.

"…and I wonder what kind of world is it where anyone can sing anyone else' song."With Angela's Ashes, Frank McCourt became the inventor of what came to be known as 'misery memoirs'. It's a detailed account of his Irish Catholic childhood in Limerick (Ireland), his struggle through the degrading and depressing life in squalor and the worst of conditions, which he has artistically sprinkled with irreverant dark humor. It's a life of such great deprivation, that all his childhood is snatched away. BUT...This seems to be predominantly the book of old Frank, and not the little Frank, which I think is unavoidable when recounting one's childhood, but in the act of doing so he may have become dishonest. I have no qualms if the author adds a bit here or there to enhance the readability of the book, yet it's not seldom when the question pops in my mind - "Is McCourt reliable at all?"McCourt's side:McCourt thinks his critics are missing the point. ‘Angela’s Ashes and ’Tis are not autobiographies, they are memoirs – and they are not the same things. An autobiography is an attempt to bring up all the facts, and to stick to them, faithfully and chronologically. But a memoir is an impression of your life, and that gives you a certain amount of leeway. If an autobiography is like a photograph, then a memoir is more like a painting. So I’ve always said to my critics, This is my impression of my life, so what are you gonna do about it?’Okay! We got it.
My Conclusion:
 I feel we're being led from street to street of an unknown land, holding the hand of a complete stranger, which maybe both good and bad.

A sad yet humorous memoir of Irish childhood... Angela’s Ashes by Frank Mc Court as reviewed by Gail M.Murray Frank Mc Court’s memoir covers his life from age 4 to 19 in Limerick, Ireland during the 1930’s and 1940’s. It is a sad Irish Catholic childhood with an alcoholic father, pompous priests, bullying schoolmasters, illness, and death of 3 of his siblings yet his humor, pathos and perseverance shine through. It is an emotional and compelling read.  Mc Court published Angela’s Ashes in 1996, won a Pulitzer in 1997 and the movie was released in 1999 starring Robert Carlyle and Emily Watson. The story of his childhood was always there in his mind when he attended English courses at New York University and wrote a piece about waking up with fleas in the mattress, when he and brother Malachy improvised then performed their memories and brought the house down. He taught creative writing at Peter Stuyvestant High School in prestigious Manhattan and wrote to encourage his students. Yet is was in his sixties and encouraged by his third wife Ellen that he wrote it all down. The editor barely changed anything; the story was deep in his marrow. Sometimes she would find him in turmoil and tears. He had to forgive before he could write. Though his father’s alcoholism left them starving and desperate, he never condemned him. My favourite passage in the book is the way he describes his father: “I think my father is like the Holy Trinity with three people in him, the one in the morning who makes us tea and reads the paper, the one at night with the stories and prayers and then the one who does the bad thing and comes home with the smell of whiskey and wants us to die for Ireland.”(p210).  Frank almost does die from the squalid living conditions, ending up in the hospital with typhoid, taking two and a half months to recover. It is the first time he sleeps in a bed with clean white sheets and gets regular nutritious meals. How anyone can survive on tea and fried bread is a wonder.  Although his mother did her best to scrape through without help from her cruel family, it bothered me that she always had money for cigarettes – her one indulgence. At that time, women could not collect the dole, jobs were few and there was no child care. As a Catholic she was obliged to service her husband. Birth control was illegal in Ireland until 1980. Angela bore seven children and lost three of them as babies to pneumonia. Her only daughter Margaret died at seven weeks of age. His memoir deals with major themes: poverty, religion (the church is pervasive in their everyday lives), classes, misplaced pride, coming of age. The tone is conversational, colloquial and engaging. We see through the child’s perspective, an observant child with an ironic sense of humor. Frank was the eldest and grew up fast stealing bread, milk and apples to feed his brothers as their father drank their money away. At 13 he was working full time as a telegram delivery boy. Throughout the book, he is serious, clever and street smart – a survivor- and we cheer him on! Mc Court wrote two other memoirs: ‘Tis about his early adult years as an immigrant in New York City and Teacher Man which elaborates his teaching career.  When interviewed he said: “Doggedness is not as glamorous as ambition, talent, intellect or charm but still the one thing that got me through the days and nights.”

Synopsis: Angela’s Ashes is the Pulitzer Prize winning memoir of Frank McCourt. The book begins in New York, where Frank’s parents met and started the family. We see the McCourts struggling with the harsh realities of poverty caused by dad’s alcoholism and inability to find work. Frank is only four years old and is already sharing the responsibilities of raising his younger siblings, while experiencing hunger, squalor, and sickness. The family moves back to Ireland during the Great Depression and their situation takes a turn for the worse. There is very little support available from their extended family and the McCourts plunge deeper into poverty and a life of misery.*** Review ***While many readers may find the book to be a very depressing read, I do not share this view. First, McCourt is a great narrator who is able to show us the crude depictions of poverty and its dramatic effects, yet does so with humor and compassion. Secondly, in spite of a bleak picture of extreme and inescapable poverty, we see Frank McCourt growing up into a young man who is responsible, hard working, and who is able to ultimately reap the benefits of his education. With every bit on money saved, Frank gets one step closer to salvation from the claws of poverty.One particular aspect that I loved about this book is McCourt’s relation with his alcoholic father, Malachy. While it was Malachy’s alcoholism that was the root of all misfortunes of the family, McCourt depicts his father with much compassion, in a way that makes it almost impossible for the readers to hate him. We frequently see glimpses of a father who deeply loves his children, who told them stories and loved teaching them about Irish history, a father who suffered immensely when three of his small children passed away, but ultimately a father with a debilitating addiction to alcohol.While this may not be a book that fits everyone’s tastes (well, what book really does?), I found this auto-biography absolutely fascinating. This is particularly because it does not simply reflect the a dramatic story of one single family. Angela’s Ashes is well written and even funny at times despite being a story of poverty, abuse, neglect, abandonment, and religious oppression. Early on, the story is very engaging but over halfway through it starts to feel repetitive. Frank McCourt has been accused of exaggerating and fabricating many elements of what is supposed to be an autobiographical work. To some extent, this is the nature of memoirs. They aren’t accurate retellings of events. They are an individual’s memories or interpretations of events. Memories aren’t snapshots of points in time. They change and become altered over the years. Two people can remember the same event very differently. Still, people who knew Frank McCourt said his family wasn’t as poor as he claimed they were. In Angela’s Ashes, McCourt says, “When I look back on my childhood I wonder how I survived at all. It was, of course, a miserable childhood: the happy childhood is hardly worth your while. Worse than the ordinary miserable childhood is the miserable Irish childhood, and worse yet is the miserable Irish Catholic childhood.” Did McCourt invent some aspects of his childhood story, sprinkling in fabrications among actual events, because he thought his real childhood wasn’t worth a reader’s while? And if many events are indeed fabricated, is it worth the reader’s while? As an example, McCourt claims the day before his confirmation a boy offered to let him spy on his naked sisters. They got caught and got into trouble. McCourt later admitted that this particular boy didn’t have any sisters. McCourt defended the book by saying it’s "a memoir, not an exact history." How much of the book is inexact? Which parts? Some things in the book ring true, like the treatment of pupils by the masters in schools and the oppressiveness of the Catholic Church in Ireland at that time. But it’s hard to know what’s real and what was added to make the book “worth your while.”Angela’s Ashes is marketed as a memoir/autobiography but semi-autobiographical seems like a much more accurate description of what readers should expect. I think if it had been properly marketed, I would have liked it more. But expecting one thing and getting another kind of ruined the experience.

Frank McCourt grew up in extreme poverty on the streets of Limerick, Ireland. His father was an alcoholic who could never keep a job and spent every bit of money on whiskey or a pint. This memoir was filled with gloomy, sorrowful pages of a desperately hungry family struggling to survive. But what I have witnessed time and time again is the kindness of the poor towards people who are even less fortunate than them. While wealthy people and people of the church slammed doors in young Frankie's face and shamed his family for needing assistance, his mother and brother were welcoming the homeless into their house for a (somewhat) dry place to spend the night. I have seen this play out so many times - why is it that the poor are more charitable than the wealthy? I googled it and there are actually studies done that confirm this. An NPR article says, "Across these experiments, the main variable that we find that consistently explains this differential pattern of giving and helping and generosity among the upper and lower class is feelings of sensitivity and care for the welfare of other people and, essentially, the emotion that we call compassion."Frankie's school experience had its ups and downs. Some of his teachers had zero patience, were quick to reprimand, and very actively discouraged questions. Another teacher gave this advice: You have to study and learn so that you can make up your own mind. Stock your mind, stock your mind. It is your house of treasure and no one in the world can interfere with it. If you won the Irish Sweepstakes and bought a house that needed furniture would you fill it with bits and pieces of rubbish? Your mind is your house and if you fill it with rubbish from the cinemas it will rot in your head. You might be poor, your shoes might be broken, but your mind is a palace.

"I think my father is like the Holy Trinity with three people in him, the one in the morning with the paper, the one at night with the stories and the prayers, and then the one who does the bad thing and comes home with the smell of whiskey and wants us to die for Ireland." Frankie's boyhood voice comes through strong as cigarette smoke in this "misery memoir" and lingers just as long; this writing is bold, funny, cinematic. One feels set down in the streets of Limerick to fend for oneself, just as the McCourts do day in and day out. There is a cyclic quality to this story: Schoolmasters question their pupils using the same conversational format no matter what the subject is. Frank's father sings nationalistic songs and exaggerates his patriotism every night he comes home from the pub. Our young hero tries to prevent his siblings from telling stories about  his  hero, the legendary figure Cuchulain. Angela is mocked and teased by the owners of the charities she begs for help. And always, always, there is hunger.This book is terribly sad; babies die, fathers drink, mothers trade sex for shelter. But it never goes beyond the pale in terms of gore or sexual content; as the narrative voice is so beautifully childlike, the worst events are revealed through euphemistic language. People are here one day and "gone" the other; babies are delivered by the Angel on the Seventh Step. There is subtle commentary on the class system and the relations between the sexes, with McCourt clearly on the side of those who suffer from oppression in any form.The ending is a little unsatisfying, but that's all the more reason for me to get a copy of the sequel, "Tis"!

He focuses on his boyhood, especially up to age twelve or so. From there he somewhat quickens the tempo up to the end of the book, when he is nineteen. McCourt, his mother, and his siblings are really handicapped by McCourt's lazy, alcoholic father. The man is a deadbeat, going for long stretches without a job, sitting at home literally doing nothing except collecting "the dole", and then immediately spending all of that in one night at various taverns. If he does get a job, he loses it by the third week due to drunkenness. To even call his attempts at trying to get employment "halfhearted" would be charitable. The man was just lazy. Since McCourt's mother, Angela, is always seemingly pregnant, she does not get a job either. She tries to take care of the children as best she can in whatever awful apartment or relative's home they are staying at, but with a no-good husband, she is forced to go plead for donations from charities, and then finally beg for food. Not until very late in the book, after Frank is already no longer living with her, does she get a job caring for an old man. Unfortunately, Frank's extended family is almost no better. The only one who shows him any kindness is an uncle on his mother's side, Pa Keating. Everyone else is mean, even downright cruel, to Frank and his siblings. Frank seems to bear the brunt of it since he is the oldest one, and unfortunately for him, physically resembles his father. His grandma is a mean old witch who does not miss any chance to demean him, nor does his Aunt Aggie. A cousin, Laman Griffin, is no better. But not just his family is cruel. Frank paints a portrait of a dysfunctional society where many of the men are drunks, the women pious, and almost everyone looking down on them. The children starve, get diseases (three of his siblings die), do not get adequate medical care or nourishment, and not even much schooling. Only at the very end, after a few years of hard work (and a bit of thievery), would Frank no longer be considered destitute. And perhaps that is the biggest reason that this book is so good: Frank never gives up, never stops trying to be better, does not allow himself to stay wallowed in self-pity, keeps working hard to reach his goal of returning to the United States and starting a new life. This is not an easy read. Some of the things and situations that Frank describes are horrible, especially considering that this is what the children were enduring everyday. There are many example, but one should suffice to explain what type of existence he had to endure. On page 296, he is writing of when he moved in with his mentally handicapped uncle, Pat: "He says there's no food in the house, not a scrap of bread, and when he falls asleep I take the greasy newspaper from the floor. I lick the front page, which is all advertisements for films and dances in the city. I lick the headlines. I lick the great attacks of Patton and Montgomery in France and Germany. I lick the war in the Pacific. I lick the obituaries and the sad memorial poems, the sports pages, the market prices of eggs butter and bacon. I suck the paper till there isn't a smidgen of grease. I wonder what I'll do tomorrow." It's a miracle that he made it out of Limerick City, Ireland alive.

I just finished Angela's Ashes by Frank McCourt and it was such an amazing read! Though very sad, it had moments of happiness that made me laugh out loud.The story is close to my heart. Even if we didn't experience poverty like the McCourts, I did experience deprivation in many aspects, making the story relatable and I, too, looked back in my own childhood and smile at the memories. I see my own dad in Frank's story, for my late father also experienced poverty - having to sell ice drop while he was young and having to work as a janitor at the same university where he studied college. I love stories like this, for it is indeed an inspiration. Now, I think I will buy the next book - 'Tis - because I want to know how he rose from the ashes. *SPOILERS AHEAD*Giving my five - point reaction to this book:1) The heaviest part was at the first few chapters, but even if it was too much to handle and I was on the verge of giving up, it didn't make me cry. The book made me cry, yes, but it was towards the later part of the book - especially that part where the father cut the hard boiled egg to share to his children.2) Their father wasn't a desirable man, but there were some things in him I admired. Thank you for your story.PS - Thanks Gie for telling me to read this book, this has been on my shelf for a year now and thru Gie's recommendation, I bumped it up on my TBR list.

I read ‘Tis when I was a teenager, and it’s one of those books that has always stuck with me. I’ve wanted to read  Angela’s Ashes for years. I’m glad that I finally got a chance to read it.Frank McCourt was born in depression-era New York, but poverty and his father’s drinking drove his immigrant family back to Ireland. Life in Ireland isn’t any easier for Frank. He grows up in extreme poverty and faces disease and starvation. His only goal is to become a man so that he can get a job and support his family.This memoir is pretty bleak. Frank did not have an easy childhood. His hunger, poverty, and unsanitary living conditions led to serious diseases that altered his life and killed a few of his siblings. Even though this book is difficult to read, it’s not completely depressing. There are moments of startling humor and beauty. The writing is very good. It’s blunt and occasionally vulgar. It’s honest without being melodramatic. I could really feel Frank’s desperation to make a better life for himself and his family, and I couldn’t imagine growing up like he did. This book shows humanity at its best and its worst. Frank's story has a lot of causal violence, but it also proves how kind people can be. One of my favorite scenes is when Frank steals a bag of oranges from a store. The store owner know that Frank and his siblings are starving, so instead of calling the police, the store owner gives the kids a second bag of fruit.I don’t know very much about depression/WWII era Ireland, so the political and cultural aspects of this memoir are interesting to me. The book is a firsthand account of the conflicts between the Protestants and the Catholics and the English and Irish. Being an Irish Catholic is a huge part of Frank’s identity. I liked reading about someone whose life, experiences, and beliefs are so different from mine. I enjoyed this book overall, but I have to admit that I was bored for a lot of it. I think the plot is slow, flat, and repetitive. Every time Frank starts to get ahead in life, something tragic happens that knocks him back down. This does help the reader feel Frank’s frustration, but the cycle becomes boring and predictable after a few hundred pages.If you can get past the repetition, I highly recommend this book. It provides an in-depth look at extreme poverty and makes you grateful for everything you have. I can see why some people consider it a classic and an important work of modern literature.

I’ve just finished reading 
Angela’s Ashes
 — a book I found fortuitously, but also quite fortunately, here in Brooklyn at the 8th Street Book Exchange.“Fortuitously” is perhaps not altogether accurate. I pass by this book exchange at least 2-3 times a week in the hope that I’ll spot a gem I haven’t already read. I recognized both the title and the author’s name immediately—and grabbed it. “Fortunately,” however, is entirely accurate. Why? Because I can say with confidence that 
Angela’s Ashes
 is one of the finest works of literary fiction I know of—and I’ve read many in this particular coming-of-age genre, starting decades ago with Henry Fielding’s 
Tom Jones
 and, just recently, with John Cleland’s Fanny Hill.If you’ve got a fondness for the sound of Irish brogue — and I do — 
Angela’s Ashes
 is the book for you! The prose in this book moves fast. Very fast. But I suspect that almost involuntary speed-of-read has more to do with the writer’s talent than with the brogue. It takes talent to make a reader’s eye move quickly across the page, and Frank McCourt has that talent. In spades.But he also has something else, which I’ll call a perfect pitch and feel for tragicomedy. There are passages in this book — great mountains of them — that are painful to read. There are also passages — most of them dialogue — that will make you laugh like Satan. None of them, mind you, of the knee-slapping variety, but rather of the frenzied-at-midnight, demonically celebratory variety. I dunno. Perhaps it’s just the brogue. Or Ireland. Or the Irish — surely God’s chosen wretches if there ever were such a “Chosen People.”If I have any criticism of 
Angela’s Ashes
 — any at all — it would be only this: I wish Frank McCourt would hoe his prose-gardens with more standard punctuation. It would render the his prose-roses less thorny in the plucking.That said, if I could give this book more than five stars, I would. Yes, it's that good.RRB09/04/13Brooklyn, NY

I did not like this book at all. I should have known from the fact that punctuation seemed optional to the author. As in: there were no quotes when someone was speaking. It made it very difficult to read knowing that five different people could speak in one paragraph and you had to somehow guess who was saying what. But the punctuation (bad as it was) was not the downfall of the book, the content proved to be that. I kept reading hoping for something redeeming about the story. That hope proved fruitless.The first indication I would hate the book was when the author describes, in detail, the sexual position his parents were using when he was conceived. By the way, that position is standing against a wall in a bar because the moment could not be delayed for a better time and place. The book had some deeper moments, but the way those moments were presented made it hard to have the right emotions. For instance, at times the book was quite a page turner, and sadly, for all the wrong reasons. I found myself reading on to see which of the author's siblings would die next. What a horrible place to take your mind – thinking about real children that really lived and wondering when one will get it over with and die to make the book more interesting. The book's ending is what really upset me. I was looking for something to make everything else make sense. I was looking for the boy that had lived the previous 350 pages to come out a man that would learn from those mistakes of others. A man who knew where he came from and would rise above it. The book seemed to lead us toward that ending for a while and then how did the book end? The boy grows up to break free from Ireland and escape the remnants of a life his dead-beat philandering father left for him. What does he do immediately upon his arrival to America? Has sex with a married woman. Congrats Frankie. You’ve truly got it all now. You are out of Ireland and living the American Dream (that’s doing it on American soil for those of who didn’t know).

It's not every day that you read a memoir with such feeling. Angela's ashes can represent a number of things, but I think it’s possible that they represent, above all, poverty; that as long as Frank stayed in Limerick as a messenger boy, he would become more and more closely tied to the ashes himself until he, too, would spend his adulthood by the fire, reminiscing about his wasted potential and dreaming of a better future that never materializes. As much as this is Frank’s story, it’s also his mother’s – she helped him survive, she supported him, she watched over him, wanted the best for him, and had a past of her own that was subtly entwined with his. Her ashes are the same ones that could have haunted Frank, had he followed the same course as his mother or father.Take a look at this stellar advice from the author:Everybody says, "Follow your dream." Or Joseph Campbell would say, "Follow your bliss." You have to. If it’s deep enough and authentic and profound and genuine, that’s where you have to go. If you want to put on the collar of a clergyman, go and put it on. If you want to be a barefooted monk in the Himalayas, that’s what you have to do. If you want to be a housewife, that’s what you have to do, because nature — I know. I found out eventually why I was put on this earth. I was put on this earth to write. And as Thomas Carlyle said, "Happy is the man who has found his work." So I’m happy. And I hope everybody else finds that, too.I love this book to pieces. I can’t believe how Frank McCourt managed to mix such a tragic story with humour, wit, and heartbreak. Combining fear, poverty, austerity, and strict religious authority, his childhood was relayed in such terms of misery. Frank came a long way from his corner of Limerick, and after reading his memoir I can’t help being overjoyed that he did. He deserves all of his success.

I first read this autobiography in the 90's when it was newly published, and just re-read it for my local book club. It remains one of my favorite books. It tells the story of one of the most impoverished and deprived childhoods I have ever read about, and I have read a lot of depression era books. The poor in Ireland suffered greatly during the depression years, and also in times prior, and the author's family suffered more than most due to his father's alcoholism. Many people have found this story very depressing, and I recall an acquaintance asking "Why would you want to read about that?", but I really didn't find it that way. The author writes about his childhood and his family's suffering with humor, although it is often a dry and subtle humor that I think many misinterpret. I am impressed by his ability to see the positive in people who could easily be depicted in a very negative light. We see the many good times he had with his father, who really did love his children, but who suffered from alcoholism and frequently drank all his wages or social assistance money and left his family with no food or heat. Having said that, I frequently found myself wanting to leap through the pages and knock some sense into his father, and also into his mother, who I feel could have done a lot more to ease her family's suffering. This book gives us a fascinating glimpse into Irish culture, especially the long held grudges against the English, and Northern Ireland, and the strong hold of the Catholic church over the people, which only adds to the poverty and oppression. It is truly a wonder the Frank McCourt survived his childhood and was able to look back on it and share it with us with such insight and humor.

I'd been hearing that I absolutely had to read this book for months before I finally bought a copy. And everything that I'd heard about it is true--that it's as gripping as it is disturbing. Anyone who wants to get an idea of what it was like to grow up in poverty in Ireland in the 1930's and 1940's needs to read this book. McCourt tells us at the beginning of the book, "Worse than the ordinary miserable childhood is the miserable Irish childhood, and worse yet is the miserable Irish Catholic childhood".The story starts in New York, where Frank was born, along with a sister and three brothers. His father is an alcoholic, which means that he drinks what little money the family does have. It's also the middle of the depression and Frank's mother Angela struggles just to find enough food for the kids to eat. They decide that there might be more work in Ireland, so the whole family moves back to Limerick, where the rest of the story takes place. Their luck doesn't change by going to Ireland. In fact, it gets much worse. Throughout the book, just when you think that nothing else can go wrong for Frank and his brothers, something else terrible seems to happen to them.What makes the book especially poignant is that it's told entirely through the eyes of the child that McCourt was. So what you get is a description of extreme poverty and oppression, as explained to you by a child who lived through it. Frank never stops to wonder why those around him suffer; he's too busy living the life that he describes. Maybe the most amazing thing about this book is that it manages to be so funny at times, despite how sad it is. In the end, it's as hilarious as it is tragic.

Hands-down the greatest memoir I've read, knocking off Richard Wright's 'Black Boy' from the top spot for me. This is Frank McCourt's story of growing up poor in Limerick, Ireland. As he says in the book's famous opening line: "When I look back on my childhood I wonder how I survived at all. It was, of course, a miserable childhood: the happy childhood is hardly worth your while. Worse than the ordinary miserable childhood is the miserable Irish childhood, and worse yet is the miserable Irish Catholic childhood."The whole book is written from the perspective of a child--a mode of storytelling McCourt stumbled upon (or that stumbled upon him) when he heard his four-year-old granddaughter speaking in the simple, present tense. As a result, moments that could be brutal are often tender, and there are enough laugh-out-loud scenes--especially related to priests, the Church, drinking, and sex--to make the book read quickly. There are so many themes in here because it is the portrait of a complex upbringing rendered simply and honestly. For me, one of the major themes was innocence and the loss of innocence, and how, as children, we inevitably come upon moments when all the adults in our lives disappoint us. This memoir's reputation is richly deserved. It is a masterpiece of both craft and storytelling, with an Irish flair. McCourt does in non-fiction what James Joyce did in fiction: bringing the full spectrum of his experience to life, and creating a language all to himself (and us, his readers) in the process.

Where I got the book: my bookshelf (it was assigned for one of my kids' English classes).I finally got round to reading the book after listening--twice--to the excellent audiobook, read by Frank McCourt himself. So I had the music of his voice with me as I read. But the music is also in the writing.I've often seen literary agents write that to be published, a memoir has to have a strong voice and a really unique story. McCourt wins on both accounts. Reading this book is exactly like having someone sitting opposite you, telling his story; the writing rambles on, without punctuated dialogue, and yet it's as clear as a bell.And what a story. Brutal, poignant, touching and funny. There are two points in the story which always, on audio or on the page, reduce me to tears, and both involve a priest. The memoir is steeped in Irish Catholic faith and superstition, seen from the distance of years with fond, mocking eyes. McCourt doesn't spare himself or his parents; I find myself wondering if he's left anything out at all. But the story's suffused with wisdom and understanding, even for his drink-addicted father.This is a book you should read if you want to understand what people mean when they say a writer should have a strong voice. The rhythms of McCourt's writing stayed with me for hours after I put the book down.

A tragic novel with a lot of charm and gallows humor!In the novel Frank McCourt describes his life from the birth, up to his journey to America. His life in Catholic and impoverished Ireland revolves primarily around priest, prayers, confessions and the search for food, as well as his constantly drunk father and his search for work.The history Frank McCourts is equally touching, tragically, however, also deeply funnily. The Irish population is made fun of and shown in her whole charm, goodness, however, also in her hardness, severity and patriotism. I probably laughed more than I should've but McCourt wrote this story in such a wonderful but yet touching way with some funny phrases. McCourt is not ashamed of saying the truth and the dialogues are often screamingly funny and marked at the same time by sadness.Also historically the novel offers a lot: Settled after the Free State treaty in 1922, he reflects the reactions of the population to the regained freedom of Ireland and tells about the Irish politics until the end of the Second World War. I've read this book for the first time in Italian - then moved to the English original edition. And that was the right move. In this marvellous book McCourt is able to recreate, fantastically, the melancholic musicality of the Irish language - depicting a world whose misery reaches peaks of drammatic intensity while maintaining an underlying humor that no other language could probably riproduce. I read it years ago - and still perfectly remember the incipit as well as the last words, spoken by a McCourt finally adult and emancipated by a past to which he wishes to return, probably, only to definitively abandon it. This because through his cathartic need of taking the reader behind the eyes of a child growing up in the miserable lines of an Irish village, McCourt takes you also to hear the voices surrounding him, to smell the same odors, to touch the same rough surfaces. A book full of subtle poetry, priceless humor and melancholy: wonderful.

Let me begin by saying that I love a good memoir, and you can't have a good memoir without hardship. However, the key is to learn from that hardship and become a better person through it and share your earned wisdom with your readers to teach and inspire them. If you've not done that, the book just becomes one giant, sniveling complaint like Angela's Ashes. Not only did it lack purpose, most of the characters were portrayed as frustratingly complacent and the attempts at humor were redundant and crude descriptions of indecencies and ignorance. Not once did I laugh or cry; it failed to stir any emotion in me save infuriation. I thought that eventually, if I kept on, someone would absorb something they learned from the horrors they endured and start real change in motion. No. I was left with an abrupt and sordid ending of human weakness and the potential for this pathetic story to happen all over again.

Basically, if you took the book of Job and fictionalized it, changed several details, and set it in Limerick, Ireland, it would bear a marked resemblance to this book. The writing was great, and I felt that (for once) this was a memoir that was worth writing and reading because it really gave the reader more than just someone's memories. I got a real sense of place, and life for the impoverished Irish. The experience of reading this reminded me a little of reading "The Bookseller of Kabul" -- that's the best way I can describe it. And I couldn't stop thinking, boy are my kids spoiled! Now I can add Ireland to the list of places I have no desire to visit, right after India.

What could be more fitting than to read Angela's Ashes while spending 2 weeks in Limerick? Yes, this book is depressing--but it is a memoir, and the times were tough--it's not meant to be a fairy tale. Even in modern day Limerick, it's cold and wet, and everyone is lamenting the recession--it was pretty depressing. However, much like the book, the people you meet and overall sense of community is unparalleled to other places that you will visit. It was also fun to read the book while in Limerick because the streets and landmarks referenced are all still there so it added to the sense of place. For some reason while I was reading this, my mind kept comparing Frank McCourt to sort of an Owen Meany character.

This book follows the childhood of the author Frank McCourt. It shows how difficult it was for his family to eke out a living first in Brooklyn and then in Limerick Ireland. It focuses on his family struggling to survive while his alcoholic father spent most of their money on alcohol and the heavy influence of their Catholic religion. As a fellow Catholic, I must say that I'm quite relieved that they aren't as strict now. This is not a cheery story, but it does have a few moments of wry humor that provide some much needed levity. Most of my sympathy went to Angela, Frank's mother, who must have found herself in an impossible position with so many children, not enough money and a drunk husband.

This book was an eye opener for me and made me realize and be grateful for what I have. Frank McCourt wrote about his experiences of daily survival in Ireland through a child's point of view. The book has very deep, subliminal themes, but also obvious ones too such as being appreciative and loving all even when it's hard. Also, I love the humor he wrote in. Some was very out there and strange, but some was very relatable to today's world. The ending is quite interesting to me because he equally closed his journey as well as left it on a cliffhanger for the sequel which I hope to read, 'Tis.
